elements.title: Emeliana Aiza (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that while serving in the Bolivian parliament, legislator Emeliana Aiza (pictured) took night courses to receive her high school baccalaureate?

elements.title: Hove's first public library (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that as well as books, Hove's first public library featured a disembowelling knife and a Japanese executioner's sword?

elements.title: Arthur Yorinks (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Arthur Yorinks's children's book Louis the Fish was inspired by Franz Kafka's The Metamorphosis?

elements.title: Utoro, Uji (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in Utoro, Uji, in Japan, former forced Korean laborers dodged eviction from 1945 to 2010, when they were finally able to afford buying the land in the district?

elements.title: Snu Abecassis (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Danish-Portuguese publisher Snu Abecassis was the first to publish both Pippi Longstocking and Solzhenitsyn in Portugal?

elements.title: a 1999 direct action (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that 28 Greenpeace activists partially cut down a field of genetically modified maize in a 1999 direct action in Lyng, Norfolk, but were acquitted of all charges?

elements.title: Daniel Whelan (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in 2023, Daniel Whelan became the first Irish-born NFL player since 1985?

elements.title: Ni'isjoohl totem pole (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Ni'isjoohl totem pole was once fed a diet of vacuum-packed food?
